content.html: I opened lensflare_plugin.world and deleted the light, the lens flare doesn't go away. Should it?

content.html: updated lens flare class to listen to entity_delete requests. 1d38bdf

content.raw:
Thanks, I confirmed that the lens flare disappears when the light is deleted, and comes back when a new light is added.

I also noticed that the flare's direction doesn't change when we change the camera pose. But I found a workaround in case someone wants to change the flare direction at runtime:

1. Start from a world with a single directional light
1. Insert another light
1. Place the 2nd light as desired
1. Delete the first light - the flare will be computed based on the current direction of the 2nd light

It's hacky, but it works. I'll leave it up to you whether you think it's worth responding to light pose changes. I can imagine a simulation where the position of the sun changes along the day, for example. We can always leave it as an open issue too.

Ready to approve once the CI results are back.
content.html:
Thanks, I confirmed that the lens flare disappears when the light is deleted, and comes back when a new light is added.

I also noticed that the flare's direction doesn't change when we change the camera pose. But I found a workaround in case someone wants to change the flare direction at runtime:

  1. Start from a world with a single directional light
  2. Insert another light
  3. Place the 2nd light as desired
  4. Delete the first light - the flare will be computed based on the current direction of the 2nd light

It's hacky, but it works. I'll leave it up to you whether you think it's worth responding to light pose changes. I can imagine a simulation where the position of the sun changes along the day, for example. We can always leave it as an open issue too.

Ready to approve once the CI results are back.

content.raw:
Should we mention somewhere that the flare will make light "pass through" objects?

![lensflare.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3504668068-lensflare.png)
content.html: Should we mention somewhere that the flare will make light "pass through" objects?

content.raw: It also won't take the light's color into account, right? (I'm mentioning things as potential "problems" but the answer might probably be "this is how lens flares work")
content.html: It also won't take the light's color into account, right? (I'm mentioning things as potential "problems" but the answer might probably be "this is how lens flares work")

content.raw:
updated class doxygen description. 1d38bdf

The pass through is expected as we're not handling that yet.  The color can be configured by modifying the shaders but there is no c++ APIs for doing this yet.
content.html:
updated class doxygen description. 1d38bdf

The pass through is expected as we're not handling that yet. The color can be configured by modifying the shaders but there is no c++ APIs for doing this yet.

content.raw: Is there a need to keep a pointer to the light? It looks like after we get the direction, the light is not used anymore.
content.html: Is there a need to keep a pointer to the light? It looks like after we get the direction, the light is not used anymore.

content.raw:
Suggestion, add wideangle and multi cameras to the example too. Here's what I've been testing with for example:

~~~
    <!-- wide-angle camera model with lens flare plugin -->
    <model name="wide_angle_camera_lensflare">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose>0 2 0.05 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>0.1 0.1 0.1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
        <sensor name="camera" type="wideanglecamera">
          <camera>
            <horizontal_fov>1.047</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>320</width>
              <height>240</height>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.1</near>
              <far>100</far>
            </clip>
            <lens>
              <type>gnomonical</type>
              <scale_to_hfov>true</scale_to_hfov>
              <cutoff_angle>1.5707</cutoff_angle>
              <env_texture_size>512</env_texture_size>
            </lens>
          </camera>
          <always_on>1</always_on>
          <update_rate>30</update_rate>
          <visualize>true</visualize>
          <plugin name="lensflare" filename="libLensFlareSensorPlugin.so"/>
        </sensor>
      </link>
    </model>

    <!-- multi-camera model with lens flare plugin -->
    <model name="multi_camera_lensflare">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose>0 4 0.05 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>0.1 0.1 0.1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
        <sensor type="multicamera" name="stereo_camera">
          <update_rate>30.0</update_rate>
          <camera name="left">
            <horizontal_fov>1.3962634</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>800</width>
              <height>800</height>
              <format>R8G8B8</format>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.02</near>
              <far>300</far>
            </clip>
            <noise>
              <type>gaussian</type>
              <mean>0.0</mean>
              <stddev>0.007</stddev>
            </noise>
          </camera>
          <camera name="right">
            <pose>0 -0.07 0 0 0 0</pose>
            <horizontal_fov>1.3962634</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>800</width>
              <height>800</height>
              <format>R8G8B8</format>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.02</near>
              <far>300</far>
            </clip>
            <noise>
              <type>gaussian</type>
              <mean>0.0</mean>
              <stddev>0.007</stddev>
            </noise>
          </camera>
          <visualize>true</visualize>
          <plugin name="lensflare" filename="libLensFlareSensorPlugin.so"/>
        </sensor>
      </link>
    </model>
~~~
content.html:
Suggestion, add wideangle and multi cameras to the example too. Here's what I've been testing with for example:

    <!-- wide-angle camera model with lens flare plugin -->
    <model name="wide_angle_camera_lensflare">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose>0 2 0.05 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>

        </visual>
        <sensor name="camera" type="wideanglecamera">
